awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Bayesian Inference for Interpretable Random Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Many challenging questions in data science can be characterized in terms of inference for random subsets of patients, customers, proteins, symptoms, or other experimental units. Examples include the search for a subpopulation of patients who most benefit from a given treatment, the identification of subsets of mutations that characterize different tumor cell subpopulations that could then serve as possible treatment targets, or the discovery of latent disease patterns in electronic health records that could be used to propose an improved allocation of resources.  In all three examples, the unusual nature of the inference targets as random subsets gives rise to challenging data analysis problems. In contrast, most traditional methods work for inference targets that are a single number, like a treatment effect, a level of differential protein expression, or a mean response.  This project aims to address this gap in currently available methodology by developing and applying new methods to solve several specific inference problems related to random subsets.

This project develops novel statistical inference methods for random subsets to approach such inference problems by explicitly introducing parsimony and interpretability as criteria for the reported inference. Related methods are developed for random partitions, feature allocation, and extensions of such structures. Besides the development of models and inference paradigms, a second major thrust of the proposed work is the development of computationally feasible implementations for large data sets. Model-based Bayesian inference for random subsets quickly leads to prohibitively computation-intensive implementations when simulation-exact posterior Monte Carlo methods are used. While several big data posterior simulation methods for global parameters have been developed in recent literature, there are few such methods for random subsets, i.e., local parameters. The project will explore several approaches to develop such methods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we considered inference for unknown structures such as a random partition, i.e., cluster arrangement, random graphs, random subsets, and more. The focus of the work was on developing interpretable inference, that is, inference that links formal statistical results with meaningful questions that arise from the underlying application. We proceed under the assumption that inference is implemented as statistical inference, that is, scientific questions  are cast as questions on unknown parameters and quantities in a probability model that serves as a stylized representation of the experiment under consideration.

In one sub-project we considered the use of external data to create a synthetic control cohort for a treatment only single-arm clinical trial. The main problem is how to describe the two populations, in the current study on one hand, and in the external data on the other hand. We proceed by setting up synchronized mixture models that allow us to describe and adjust for discrepancies in the two populations.

In another sub-project we explored the use of symmetries in the data, in particular separate exchangeabiltiy. The latter refers to a situation where the data appears as a rectangular matrix, for example protein activation with proteins in the columns and patients in the rows. In that case interpretable inference should start with a model that is symmetric with respect to any re-ordering of columns or rows. We discuss the princple and developed two specific modeling approaches to formally represent such symmetry in flexible non-parametric models.

In another sub-project we consider clustering when the clusters are assumed to be aligned on a graph. Such problems arise, for example, when the clusters represent homogeneous cell subpopulations and the experiment includes learning about cell differentiation. In that case we assume that clusters shoud be aligned on a tree graph representing the path of cell differentiation. Anticipating and acknowledging the alignment of custers on a graph already when forming such clusters can improve the desired inference.

The project provided important training opportunities for several graduate students, and results were widely disseminated by presentations and short courses at relevant conferences, workshops and in departmental seminars in several institutions. Work under this project motivated the planning and application for an upcoming workshop at the Banff International Research Station. The workshop is planned specifically for junior researchers and will explore frontiers of Bayesian statistical inference, including in particular the themes of this project.
